newsitem.title: UK: EU tariff move seen helping Asian coffee sector.
newsitem.headline: EU tariff move seen helping Asian coffee sector.

text.p: The European Union (EU) is to scrap its tariff on most coffee imports come January 1, a move some analysts see as benefitting mostly Asian producers at the expense of African coffee.
Western Europe is the world's largest coffee consumer after the United States.
"The big losers are African robusta producers as they now face new competition from Asia," said one Swiss-based trader. "The only way out is that they have to be more cost-effective."

Under the new EU Generalised Scheme of Preference (GSP) which starts on January 1, all green, non-decaffeinated coffee from virtually all producing countries except Brazil will enter the EU duty-free.
But coffee from the world's top grower Brazil will be subjected to 1.6 percent import duty or half of the World Trade Organisation rate of 3.3 percent.

Brazil, considered by the EU as an industrialising nation, will not enjoy the full advantage of the GSP benefit of duty-free access, Ronald Vaessen, secretary-general of the Brussels-based European Coffee Federation, told Reuters by telephone.
Coffee produced in African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) members of the Lome convention and also from least-developed nations has been enjoying free access in the 15-member EU states.
Vaessen said the new EU GSP move meant duty-free imports from Vietnam, India, Indonesia and Mexico and some others that previously had to pay a 3.3 percent duty.
"The competitive disadvantage they had is now eliminated," he said. "This will be almost the end of a negative discrimination. They will now compete on equal footing with most other competitors."
"To what extent that will create a shift (in supply)..nobody knows," he said.
Vaessen said price was not the sole determinant.
"It is the whole price-quality relationship, its shipping, its consistency of quality, reliability of supply etc," he said.
Most Asian coffee is sold at a large price discount compared with other origins. Some traders said the tariff move could tempt more European buying of Asian origins.
For example, Vietnam's Grade Two coffee trades about $250 under London futures on a FOB basis while Uganda Screen 15 coffee fetches about $55 under London, they said.
Vaessen said there were some European buyers who held back coffee imports until the new year to enjoy the tariff-free status.
"You can't completely stop your factory requirements but you do see that...to a certain extent, people wait until January to bring their coffee in," he said.

Latest European Coffee Federation figures showed western Europe imported 36.76 million 60-kg bags of coffee in calendar 1995, down from 39.0 million a year earlier. -- London Newsroom +44 171 542 4985
